Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Hierarchical Probabilistic Models for Networks with Rich Data in Scientific Domains

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will create advanced algorithms for automatically extracting and evaluating the hierarchical organization of real-world networks. Networks are a ubiquitous feature of complex social and biological systems, including species or genetic interaction networks, online social or offline friendship networks, and more. Interest in networks now spans nearly every scientific discipline. Increasingly, however, answering key scientific questions about complex networks requires new algorithms that can automatically extract their underlying organizational patterns from rich network data, and connect these patterns with scientific hypotheses. This project creates computational methods that can, for example, recursively separate a network's core from its periphery, distinguish local and global connectivity patterns within a network, and relate these patterns to auxiliary information about vertex attributes and connection strengths and types.

In particular, this project will use state-of-the-art probabilistic generative models to: (1) Create advanced algorithms that automatically extract general forms of hierarchical patterns in connectivity, in a manner that is readily interpretable by scientists; (2) Create evaluation methods for distinguishing between alternative structural patterns and for detecting random patterns; (3) Characterize their limitations when applied to answer broad classes of scientific questions and data types, and; (4) Apply these algorithms, in collaboration with domain experts, to answer specific questions about the structure and function of real networks, for example, interactions among biological species, gene recombinations in human pathogenic species, and social interactions among humans. The results of this project will generate new insights into a wide variety of socially and biologically important domains.

In addition to creating advanced algorithms with broad applications across science, this project will train new graduate and undergraduate students in cutting-edge research techniques within the interdisciplinary field of network science, develop and disseminate new educational material on network science, disseminate public-domain software implementations of algorithms, and address real scientific questions in collaboration with scientists from physics, biology, public health, and statistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to (1) create new advanced algorithms that can automatically and accurately extract the underlying structural patterns of network data, e.g., when nodes in the network tend to cluster together into functional groups or modules, and whose results would improve with access to richer types of data; (2) characterize both the fundamental limitations of these methods for answering scientific questions and the limitations of network assumptions for modeling real systems; and (3) apply these algorithms, in collaboration with domain experts, to improve our understanding of the structure and function of specific networks, e.g., interactions among proteins, recombinations among genes in human pathogenic species, and social interactions among humans.
This project created multiple new advanced probabilistic models for detecting and extracting large-scale structural patterns in networks that may vary over time or that have nodes annotated with attributes. These methods were applied to study networks of biological species interactions, social interactions, the structure of the internet, and gene recombination networks. In applications to systems biology, node attributes are often corrupted by measurement noise. This project also created a general class of network "filters" that leverage a molecular network's structure to remove noise in system-wide measurements prior to subsequent analyses. These filters were applied to predict changes in protein expression levels when human tissues become cancerous. The algorithms created by this project were made publicly available as open source implementations for use by other researchers.
In addition, this project reshaped our understanding of the fundamental limitations of network models and methods. The project identified the limiting conditions under which some of the most powerful available network models can accurately recover hidden group structures, and quantified how rich data can shift, but not eliminate, these limits. The project produced several mathematically general proofs of these limitations, meaning they apply to all network methods. Of particular importance was an extension of the famous No Free Lunch theorem to networks, which proves that no such network method is always best, over all networks. This theorem implies that the best particular network algorithm to use will depend on both the data being analyzed and the scientific question being asked. Additionally, the project investigated the practical consequences of these theorems using the largest and most diverse set of real-world networks, thereby providing strong generality, and created a new statistical framework for evaluating and comparing them. Finally, the project extended this analysis to quantify the limits to accurately predicting missing links in networks, which is a common problem in applications, e.g., in biology, commerce, etc., showing that, as with detecting group structure, no one algorithm performs best (or worst) at predicting missing links across real-world networks. The project then created a new algorithm, using model stacking to combine a large number of individual predictors across three large families of network methods, to construct an algorithm that is nearly optimal at link prediction for real-world networks.
Finally, this project contributed to the assembly of the largest publicly available list of real-world network datasets, spanning all domains of science, located at https://icon.colorado.edu. These contributions allowed the project to develop several large datasets containing hundreds of empirical networks, which the project used to thoroughly evaluate the limitations of network models, and to test popular assumptions about network structure that underlie many network methods. The network datasets created by this project were made publicly available for replication and reuse by other researchers.
The project also provided state-of-the-art training in advanced computational and statistical techniques, network data analysis, scientific writing and presentations, and research design to five postdoctoral researchers, five graduate students, and five undergraduate students. The algorithms and results produced by this project have had a broad impact in other fields, particularly in the life and social sciences, where network data and methods are increasingly common. And, a number of the datasets produced by this project have also been used by researchers in other fields.
